title: The NFC East: A Division in Transition
description: A deep dive into the coaching carousel and competitive landscape of the NFC East heading into 2026, featuring insights on the Eagles, Commanders, Cowboys, and Giants.
content:
Thank you to Ameya Idate for writing this article.

As the NFL regular season winds down, a strange silence has settled over the playoff bracket. For the first time since 2017, the postseason will not feature Patrick Mahomes, Lamar Jackson, or Joe Burrow. While most of the attention is on the Lombardi Trophy hunt, there is no shortage of drama among the teams already looking ahead to 2026. Front offices across the league are deep into the coaching carousel, reshaping staffs and philosophies in hopes of building a Super Bowl contender. In the middle of all this movement, one division in particular stands out as a focal point for change and competition: the NFC East.

A division often mocked as the "NFC Least" is quietly transforming into the most volatile and fascinating pressure cooker in professional football. Only the Philadelphia Eagles survived to see the 2025 postseason, but as we look toward 2026, the entire division is undergoing a radical, high-stakes facelift.

Let's start with the defending division champs, the Philadelphia Eagles. They finished the regular season at 11-6, but they are a team grappling with a sudden identity crisis. The Eagles have shown significant offensive struggles compared to their previous season. This is largely due to losing their offensive coordinator, Kellen Moore, and replacing him with Kevin Patullo. Despite having former Offensive Player of the Year Saquon Barkley and the elite receiving duo of A.J. Brown and DeVonta Smith, the unit has regressed sharply. The run game essentially collapsed, losing nearly 40 percent of its rushing yardage per game and falling from 2nd in the league to below average. Compared to 2024, yards per game are down 17.4 percent and points are down 14.7 percent.

The defense has been the only thing keeping the lights on in South Philly. As the offseason looms, the questions are existential. Does Patullo get another season? Does the team trade a frustrated A.J. Brown to reset the locker room culture? How the Eagles answer these questions will determine if they remain the division kingpins or if their championship window is slammed shut by the rivals gaining on them.

The Washington Commanders are coming off a largely disappointing season that failed to capture the magic of the year prior. In the 2024-2025 season, the Commanders fought their way to a conference championship behind rookie Jayden Daniels. Daniels, an ultra-athletic dual threat out of LSU, drew frequent comparisons to Lamar Jackson and delivered a historical rookie season. However, after a year plagued with injuries, Washington could not find that same rhythm. They finished the regular season 5-12, which is seven more losses than the previous year.

The organization is now hitting the reset button on the staff. While head coach Dan Quinn remains, the team is parting ways with offensive coordinator Kliff Kingsbury and defensive coordinator Joe Witt Jr. These moves effectively put Quinn on the hot seat for the 2026 season. The front office has placed the blame on the coordinators, and by giving Quinn the power to pick his new staff, they have also given him a high set of expectations. This team is no longer just looking to compete. They are looking to prove they weren't one-hit wonders.

Moving on to Dallas, the Cowboys continue to be the league's mark of mediocrity. Season after season, fans are delivered high expectations followed by disappointing results. This year was no different. The Cowboys finished 7-9-1 and missed the playoffs entirely. Looking at the box scores, you wouldn't expect such a record. Dak Prescott had the 3rd highest passing yards in the league and WR George Pickens had the 3rd highest receiving yards. Statistically, Dallas has one of the best offenses in the league, ranking 1st in yards per game and sitting in the 97th percentile for efficiency.

Their primary struggle comes from the other side of the ball. Despite entering the offseason with stars like Micah Parsons and Trevon Diggs, the defense lacked any sense of stability. The blockbuster trade sending Micah to Greenbay, and then the Cowboys making the splash move of getting Quinnen Williams from the Jets has led to a chaotic and wildly inconsistent defense. This culminated in the recent firing of defensive coordinator Matt Eberflus. Dallas is a team with a world-class engine but flat tires. If they can finally figure out the defensive side of the ball, they have the firepower to make some serious noise in the division.

Finally, we look at the young and energetic Giants. New York moved on from head coach Brian Daboll midseason, a move that typically signals a team is throwing in the towel. After losing star wideout Malik Nabers to an ACL tear and their spark-plug running back Cam Skattebo to a season-ending injury, the team fell onto a losing track. However, the future remains bright because the Giants boast one of the youngest rosters in the NFL. Rookie quarterback Jaxon Dart exceeded all expectations, and on the flip side of the ball Abdul Carter emerged as a promising edge rusher to close the season. With most of their talent still on rookie contracts and a top 5 draft pick on the way, the pieces are there for a quick turnaround. If the Giants can find the right head coach to mentor this young core along with another stellar draft from GM Joe Schoen, they will be more than capable of competing for a division title.

As the NFL shifts its focus to 2026, the NFC East has emerged as one of the league’s most unpredictable pressure points. Philadelphia is fighting to preserve its window, Washington is trying to prove last year wasn’t a fluke, Dallas is searching for defensive stability to match its elite offense, and New York is betting on youth and upside to accelerate a rebuild. Once mocked, the division is now defined by volatility, urgency, and opportunity: and whichever team solves its problems first could seize control of the conference’s most chaotic race.

title: The Impact of Analytics: Beyond the Box Score
description: An exploration of why raw scoring isn't everything in the NBA. Comparing the offensive gravity of stars like Zach LaVine to the 'glue' impact of role players like Alex Caruso and Jrue Holiday.
content:
Imagine you are an NBA general manager and you have to choose between two players. Player A is an offensive flamethrower. He is averaging 20 points, 5 rebounds, and 5 assists. He has the highlights, the athleticism, and the star label. Player B looks like a bench warmer on paper. He averages 10 points and 3 assists. If you look at the box score after a game, Player A is the one getting the headlines.

But if you look at the win column, everything flips. In the 2023 season, Zach LaVine (Player A) often saw the Chicago Bulls play better while he was on the bench. He had a staggering negative 18.8 On/Off rating at one point. This means the team was nearly 19 points better per 100 possessions when their star sat down. Meanwhile, Alex Caruso (Player B) was the heartbeat of the team. Caruso did not just have a positive net rating; he had a positive net rating with almost every single teammate he shared the floor with.

This is the fundamental shift in how we perceive basketball. Analytics has taught us that a star who scores 20 but is a cone on defense is often less valuable than a role player who shuts down the other team's best scorer. A player who stands still while opponents blow past him is a liability regardless of his scoring average.

The internet often debates who is the better hooper, but the better question is how does this player scale. The 2021 Brooklyn Nets are the ultimate cautionary tale of the engine problem. On paper, having Kevin Durant, James Harden, and Kyrie Irving was a cheat code. They had three of the greatest offensive engines in history.

The problem is that a basketball game only has one ball and 100 possessions. When you have three players who all need a 30 percent usage rate to be effective, you reach a point of diminishing returns. Analytics showed that while their offensive rating was historic, their defensive infrastructure was non-existent. They were all engines and no grease.

Because they lacked glue guys like Caruso, the team was fragile. These are players who are happy to have a 10 percent usage rate but provide 100 percent effort on the margins. When one engine stalled due to injury, the whole machine collapsed. They had not built a system that valued efficiency and defense over raw point totals.

Compare the Nets to the 2021 Milwaukee Bucks, the very same that eliminated them. Before they traded for Jrue Holiday, the Bucks were a regular season powerhouse that struggled in the playoffs. They replaced Eric Bledsoe with Holiday. While Holiday's raw scoring numbers were not always massive, his impact was astronomical.

In the 2021 NBA Finals, Jrue Holiday had games where he shot 4 for 20. In the old days, fans would have called for his head. But the analytics told a different story. Even when his shot was not falling, his defensive presence was so suffocating that he was a plus 15 on the floor. He won possession after possession on the margins. He produced screen assists and forced deflections. He stayed attached to the opponent's best player like glue.

The Bucks won that championship because they realized that surrounding a superstar like Giannis with hyper-efficient connectors is more valuable than adding a second high-volume, low-defense scorer. They traded for a guy who could score 27 in a Game 5 but was just as happy to score 12 if it meant getting the win.

We used to live in a world of what ifs and eye tests. We used to argue that a guy was good just because he looked like a star. Analytics has killed that era. We now know that a player can average 20 points and 10 rebounds while being the reason their team loses. If those 20 points come on 45 percent true shooting and those 10 rebounds are uncontested, that player is a ghost in the machine.

The box score is a skeleton, but analytics is the flesh and blood of the game. It tells us that basketball is not about who can put the ball in the hoop the most. It is about who can maximize the value of every single second they spend on the floor.

title: The First Post: Setting Up the Site
description: A quick look at the process of building this minimalist, weather-reactive portfolio using React and Tailwind.
content: Welcome to my new personal site. This project was born out of a desire for a clean, typography-focused space to share thoughts on sports, data, and media. Built with React and Tailwind CSS, it features a dynamic weather system and three distinct themes (Light, Dark, and Sunset). I'll be using this space to document my projects and share my findings in the world of sports analytics.
